citations.narrative:
The facility's records are not being kept as required. The establishment did not record the following information:
• Numbers and dates of budgie dispositions
• Disposition dates of an eastern spotted skunk, a lowland paca, a ground squirrel, domestic ducks, and a sugar glider
• The dates numerous animals were transported between sites 001 and 002
• The dates each domestic duck hatched
Accurate records of animals on hand, including records of transportation and of acquisition/disposition (purchases/births
and sales/deaths) are necessary to assess the health and wellbeing of the animals on site and allow tracking of animals
being used for regulatory purposes.
Acquisition records shall include:
• The date the animal was acquired
• The species of the animal
• The name and address of the person from whom the animal was acquired
• The USDA license or registration number of the person from whom the animal was acquired if those individuals are
licensed under the Act, OR the vehicle license number and state and the driver's license number and state of the person if
they are not licensed under the Act
• The number of animals in the shipment.
Disposition records shall include:
• The date the animal was sold or died
• The species of the animal
• If sold or given: the name and address of the person to whom the animal was sold or given
• If sold or given: the USDA license or registration number of the person to whom the animal was sold or given if they are
licensed under the Act, OR the vehicle license number and state and the driver's license number and state of the person if
they are not licensed under the Act
• The number of animals in the shipment.
The facility must maintain a record of acquisitions and dispositions for all regulated animals and ensure all required
information is properly and accurately documented at all times.
Correct by September 1, 2025.

The facility does not have an effective pest control program in place to control mammalian pests. There is an
accumulation of rodent droppings in the back kitchen in cabinets and under the sink. The kitchen is primarily used to
prepare kangaroo bottles. There is an accumulation of rodent droppings in the storage corner next to the hay bales. The
hay is used to feed ruminants and kangaroos. The inspector observed a mouse running across the back office during the
inspection.
Pests can post a hazard to the health and wellbeing of the animals by either injuring them, exposing them to potential
diseases and illness, or contaminating their food.
Correct by July 31, 2025 by establishing and maintaining a safe and effective program for the control of insects,
ectoparasites, and avian and mammalian pests.

The single water wading pool in the duck enclosure containing nine domestic ducks is not large enough to comfortably
allow the ducks to express natural behaviors. The round, plastic wading pool measured approximately 4 feet in diameter
and one foot deep. The pool was half-filled with water. During the inspection, one duck was standing in the pool and the
water came up to the tops of her legs.
Failure to provide a pool or other aquatic area of sufficient surface area and depth, for all aquatic birds in the enclosure to
be able to express natural behaviors, can lead to increased stress and a decline in physical condition.
Primary enclosures housing wading and aquatic birds must contain a pool or other aquatic area and a dry area that allows
easy ingress or egress of the pool or other aquatic area. Pools and other aquatic areas must be of sufficient surface area
and depth to allow each bird to make normal postural and social adjustments, such as immersion, bathing, swimming, and
foraging, with adequate freedom of movement and freedom to escape from aggression demonstrated by other birds in the
enclosure.
Correct by July 31, 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.75(b)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The facility's records are not being kept as required. The establishment did not record the following information:  
• Numbers and dates of budgie dispositions 
• Disposition dates of an eastern spotted skunk, a lowland paca, a ground squirrel, domestic ducks, and a sugar glider 
• The dates numerous animals were transported between sites 001 and 002 
• The dates each domestic duck hatched 
 
Accurate records of animals on hand, including records of transportation and of acquisition/disposition (purchases/births 
and sales/deaths) are necessary to assess the health and wellbeing of the animals on site and allow tracking of animals 
being used for regulatory purposes.  
 
Acquisition records shall include: 
• The date the animal was acquired 
• The species of the animal 
• The name and address of the person from whom the animal was acquired 
• The USDA license or registration number of the person from whom the animal was acquired if those individuals are 
licensed under the Act, OR the vehicle license number and state and the driver's license number and state of the person if 
they are not licensed under the Act 
• The number of animals in the shipment. 
 
Disposition records shall include: 
• The date the animal was sold or died 
• The species of the animal 
• If sold or given: the name and address of the person to whom the animal was sold or given 
• If sold or given: the USDA license or registration number of the person to whom the animal was sold or given if they are 
licensed under the Act, OR the vehicle license number and state and the driver's license number and state of the person if 
they are not licensed under the Act 
• The number of animals in the shipment.

The facility must maintain a record of acquisitions and dispositions for all regulated animals and ensure all required 
information is properly and accurately documented at all times. 
 
Correct by September 1, 2025. 
3.131(d) 
   
Sanitation. 
The facility does not have an effective pest control program in place to control mammalian pests. There is an 
accumulation of rodent droppings in the back kitchen in cabinets and under the sink. The kitchen is primarily used to 
prepare kangaroo bottles. There is an accumulation of rodent droppings in the storage corner next to the hay bales. The 
hay is used to feed ruminants and kangaroos. The inspector observed a mouse running across the back office during the 
inspection.  
 
Pests can post a hazard to the health and wellbeing of the animals by either injuring them, exposing them to potential 
diseases and illness, or contaminating their food.  
 
Correct by July 31, 2025 by establishing and maintaining a safe and effective program for the control of insects, 
ectoparasites, and avian and mammalian pests. 
3.153(c) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
The single water wading pool in the duck enclosure containing nine domestic ducks is not large enough to comfortably 
allow the ducks to express natural behaviors. The round, plastic wading pool measured approximately 4 feet in diameter 
and one foot deep. The pool was half-filled with water. During the inspection, one duck was standing in the pool and the 
water came up to the tops of her legs.  
 
Failure to provide a pool or other aquatic area of sufficient surface area and depth, for all aquatic birds in the enclosure to 
be able to express natural behaviors, can lead to increased stress and a decline in physical condition. 
 
Primary enclosures housing wading and aquatic birds must contain a pool or other aquatic area and a dry area that allows 
easy ingress or egress of the pool or other aquatic area. Pools and other aquatic areas must be of sufficient surface area 
and depth to allow each bird to make normal postural and social adjustments, such as immersion, bathing, swimming, and 
foraging, with adequate freedom of movement and freedom to escape from aggression demonstrated by other birds in the 
enclosure. 
 
Correct by July 31, 2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
